STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
September 18, 2025
Jennifer Hope Stevens
Samaritas - Southeast
8131 E. Jefferson Ave.
Detroit, MI, 48214-2610
RE: License#: CB820201265
Dear Ms. Stevens:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 9/11/2025 . Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Samantha Way, area manager at 517-243-9743.
Sincerely,
Pinkey Brown, Licensing Consultant
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12312 Foster parent training
• (4) At least 1 adult member of the household must have training in
and maintain a current certification in first aid and cardiopulmonary
resuscitation from the American Heart Association or the American
Red Cross, or other institution approved by the department.
One of six foster home case records reviewed did not have documentation of a
current first aid and cardiopulmonary resuscitation certification.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child and
parent or parents, as follows:
• (b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
Two of six foster care case records and one independent living case record
reviewed did not complete the updated service plans within 90 days.
Repeat Violation Established
2024 Interim, CAP approved 3/7/2025
Special Investigation #2024SIC0001751, dated 11/24/2024, CAP approved
3/7/2025.

CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (5) An agency shall involve the child's parent or parents and the
foster parents in the development of service plans to enable the
parent or parents and foster parents to understand the plan for the
child and the parents' and the foster parent's role in assisting the
agency in carrying out the plan. An agency shall give a copy to and
review the parent-agency treatment plan with the parent or parents
and foster parents. The agency must inform the parent or parents and
foster parent that the information in the parent-agency treatment plan
and any other information about the child and the child's family is
confidential.
Four of six foster care case records and three of three independent living case
records reviewed did not indicate that the plan was developed with the
parent/parents or foster parents to enable the parent/parents/foster parents to
understand the plan.
Repeat Violation Established
Special Investigation #2024SIC0001751, dated 11/24/2024, CAP approved
3/7/2025.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:.
• Technical Assistance was not requested or required.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Consultation was not requested or required.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.

There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance:
The agency has submitted 2 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
Special Investigation #2024SIC0001751, dated 11/24/2024, CAP approved on
12/30/2024. The allegations involved home visits in the caregiver’s home and no
home visit sheets were completed and signed. The agency was found in violation
with CPA Rule 400.12202 (1) and three additional rules, 400.12207 (3), 400.12418
(2) (b) and 400.12418 (5). The agency was found in repeat violations during this
reporting period in their renewal inspection of 400.12418 (2) (b) and 400.12418
(5). The agency has put forth efforts to correct these violations.
The agency interim inspection was completed on 12/6/2024, and the CAP was
approved on 3/7/2025. The agency was found in violations with six CPA rules.
There is one rule that is a repeat violation for this reporting period, Rule 400.12418
(2) (b). More effort is needed to correct this violation.
Chief Administrator Assessment:
Chief Administrator (CA) discussed barriers that impeded the agency this year
during the onsite inspection. The CA reported during this reporting period, there
was a restructuring, which included transition of staff, including chief
administrator/director and program managers. There were some layoffs and other
staff transitioned to different supervisors. These changes have been a challenge
for staff, which affected staff retention. CA reported the CAP allowed the team to
review how to more effectively track due dates. The caseworkers are using their
Book of Business reports more and supervisors are reviewing them weekly with
their teams. Supervisors are meeting with their teams weekly to discuss what is
due and any potential barriers to completing their work timely.
Financial Overview:
The independent agency auditor’s report dated December 31, 2023, and the
agency annual financial report was reviewed. There were no financial concerns
identified.
Staff Interviews:
Staff interviewed reported they get the assistance and support they need from
their coworkers on their teams and supervisors. Staff reported if they could
change anything about the program it would be to hire more case aides and to
have meetings with other programs within the agency to get to know their
coworkers and have more cohesiveness with one another.

Description of Agency Walk Through:
The agency has the space and equipment needed to fulfil job requirements. The
files are stored securely to prevent unauthorized access.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS:
There were three safety alerts.
Safety Alert 1:
Concern: Caregiver did not have an operable smoke detector on each level of
occupancy and/or near all sleeping areas.
Resolution: The caregiver already had the smoke detector in her possession.
The agency caseworker assisted the caregiver in getting the smoke detector
installed on 7/2/2025 and the home is in compliance.
Safety Alert 2:
Concern: Caregiver did not have an operable smoke detector near all sleeping
areas.
Resolution: A smoke detector was installed in the area that was cut off when
the hall door closes. There are now two smoke detectors between the
bedrooms and the rest of the home. The smoke detector was placed adjacent
to the light fixture that was shown in the safety alert. The home is now in
compliance with all licensing rules.
Safety Alert 3:
Concern: Caregiver had no operable smoke detector on each level of
occupancy and/or near all sleeping areas. There was no operable carbon
monoxide detector in the home. The boiler room is being used as a bedroom
for one of the youth in the home and the room is occupied by the water heater,
washer and dryer.
Resolution: On 7/3/2025, the Licensing Supervisor discussed the current safety
plan regarding the sexualized behaviors of the youths in the home and new
bedroom arrangements were developed. The caregiver will now be sleeping
on the couch, one youth will be sleeping in the caregiver’s bedroom and the other
youth will be sleeping in the other room that was for the two youths. It was
discussed that it was inappropriate for the youths to share a sleeping space.
The space that previously held a bed in the laundry room area will now be
used for storage. Three dual smoke and carbon detectors were provided by
the agency and installed by the caregiver. Caregiver’s home is in compliance
with licensing requirements.

VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action
plan, it is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their
regular license.
9/16/2025
